ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In-depth knowledge about prison system and alternatives, philosophical approaches to prisonization and conversations about abolition.
The history of college and prisons as institutions and what happens when the two are combined. Also discussed ideas such as abolition, liberation, transformation, and education.
I learned a lot about the purpose and function of education and the prison industrial complex and how, together, they help each other achieve their respective objectives.
Learned to think critically about colleges, prisons, and the intersection between the two

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I cannot emphasize enough how much I appreciated the guest speakers that we had in our class, and how talking/listening to them provided so many insights into carceral logics that we read about prior to class.
Shawn and Zelda are both fantastic instructors. I enjoyed the class visitors. The only weakness is that I wished Yale would grant Shawn instructor status.

I loved the course format, particularly its situation around guests. College in prison and prison more broadly are one of those things that can only truly be understood by those that have experienced them, and having guests, many of which were formerly imprisoned or wrote extensively on the subject, was absolutely invaluable for our understanding of the subject matter. Apart from that, I really liked the discussion setup and general orientation of the course. That said, I think there were times the syllabus/course material got a bit repetitive.

Having Zelda, Marcus, Shawn, Clyde, and Carl around made every class something to look forward to. The guest speakers were always really interesting since they had different backgrounds but all had experience with CIP programs. The trajectory of topics was well laid out, starting out with contexts and histories and building up to larger institutional questions as we got further along in the semester.
Strengths: many guest visitors that bring their individual insights, kind and understanding professors, good class community, engaging assignments Weaknesses: a lot of heavy reading

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! You will not regret it- easily the best class I have taken at Yale.

I would! College in prison can only be truly understood by those who have experienced it, and this course's embeddedness within the college in prison system makes it fascinating. You learn from previously incarcerated people about the nature of education, its impacts on them, and broader philosophical takes on incarceration. If you are at all interested in mass incarceration, i highly recommend this class.
Definitely! This has been my favorite class at Yale.

Absolutely. Zelda is an amazing instructor who spotlights different voices that widen our perspective for each week's topic. She is also incredibly understanding and kind, and I enjoyed learning from her and the many guest instructors she brought in.
